bibliographic-data.invention-title: INVESTMENT FUNDS ENABLING A BOND LADDERING STRATEGY

abstract.p: An open-ended fund, such as an ETF, holds fixed-income securities and has a liquidation date. An order management system receives buy orders from a plurality of investors for purchasing shares of the fund receives and sell orders from a plurality of investors for selling shares of the fund. A fund management information system determines a yield for each investor based on the shares of the fund purchased by the investor and the fixed-income securities held by the fund at the time that the shares were purchased. The fund management information system also determines a plurality of distribution payments and a final liquidation payment for each investor so that the distribution payments and the final liquidation payment provide the yield determined for the investor when the investor purchased shares of the fund. This enables investors to use the fund in a bond laddering strategy.

nplcit.text: - Mullan, S., "Investing; Bond Funds for Wary and Bold Investors," Business Day, The New York Times, Aug. 11, 2002, 2 pages
- American Century Investments, "American Century Investments Prospectus," Feb. 1, 2013, 40 Pages
- Goldsticker, R., "A Mutual Fund to Yield Annuity-Like Benefits," Financial Analyst Journal, Jan.-Feb. 2007, pp. 63-67, vol. 63, No. 1
- Jeffery, C., "Morgan Stanley set to launce European synthetic 'Tracer'," Risk, May 3, 2002, 2 pages
- Oey, P., "New Bond Funds for Building Ladder Portfolios," Morningstar, Jun. 4, 2010, 3 pages
